dimensions.name: Concept Clarity
dimensions.description: How clearly the teacher explains Python concepts, syntax, and idioms.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Uses simple definitions; illustrates each concept with clear, runnable code snippets; explains why a construct is used.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Provides vague explanations; mixes unrelated topics; uses jargon without definition.

dimensions.name: Delivery & Communication
dimensions.description: Voice clarity, pacing, enthusiasm, and ability to convey Python ideas effectively.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Clear, audible voice; varied tone to highlight important points; steady pace that allows learners to follow code examples.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Monotone delivery; speaks too quickly or too slowly; excessive filler words that distract from the code.

dimensions.name: Content Structure
dimensions.description: Logical flow of Python lessons: introduction → core concept → live coding example → summary and next steps.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Starts with problem context, presents the syntax, demonstrates a live example, then recaps key takeaways and suggests practice tasks.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Jumps between topics without transitions; presents code before explaining its purpose; lacks a concluding summary.

dimensions.name: Student Engagement
dimensions.description: Interaction with learners, prompting them to think, write code, and ask questions about Python.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Poses open‑ended questions, encourages learners to predict output, uses interactive coding exercises, checks understanding frequently.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Delivers a one‑way lecture; never asks for input or checks if learners can run the code themselves.

dimensions.name: Accuracy
dimensions.description: Correctness of Python syntax, semantics, and best‑practice recommendations.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: All code runs without errors; explanations align with the official Python documentation; follows PEP 8 style guidelines.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Shows code with syntax errors; misstates language behavior; recommends deprecated modules or anti‑patterns.
